Fax: + 91 376 2370011. Graphical abstract The catalyst precursors, [Rh(CO)2Cl-ligand(L)-APTMS-montmorillonite] (1a and 1b, where, a and b correspond to ligand (L)-APTMS-montmorillonite for ligands L=Quinoline-2-carboxylic acid (L1) and Quinoline-8-carboxylic acid (L2) respectively; APTMS=(3-aminopropyl)-trimethoxysilane), have been synthesised. The montmorillonite was activated by treating with formic acid under controlled condition to increase the surface area and pore volume prior to functionalization by APTMS and subsequent anchoring with the ligands. 1a and 1b were characterized by CHN, FT-IR, powder XRD, N2-sorption and SEM-EDX analysis. The efficacy of the catalysts was evaluated in carbonylation of methanol to acetic acid and found to exhibit catalytic conversion up to 99.9%. The catalysts were recovered and reused for several runs without any significant loss of catalytic efficiency. Keywords Anchoring Functionalization Rhodium Montmorillonite Carbonylation 1 Introduction Acetic acid is one of the vital chemical used in laboratory as well as for industrial process [1–3]. It is used in very large scale in industries like textile, food processing, ink & printing adhesive etc. The most common way for industrial production of acetic acid is the catalytic carbonylation of methanol by Monsanto’s process. The active species in Monsanto’s process is [Rh(CO)2I2]− which works together with co-catalyst CH3I [4–7]. Considerable efforts are being made in order to improve the catalyst in various ways by incorporating different ligands into the coordination sphere of the catalyst [8–14]. Among these, ligands containing P, N or N∼O atoms are more widely studied because of their σ-bonding and π-back bonding capacity (for P atom) through which they can stabilize low valent metals. Furthermore because of their good σ-donating ability, they make the metal center more electron rich. As a result, the metal center becomes more susceptible to oxidative addition, which is the primary step of carbonylation reaction [1,2,14–30]. However, all these catalytic processes are homogeneous in nature and always associated with problems of catalyst separation and reusability, which is very important from the point of economic viability. This problem can be overcome by using heterogeneous catalyst or by immobilizing homogeneous catalyst on heterogeneous support for easy separation. A large number of studies have already been reported on the anchoring of such metal complexes onto the solid inorganic supports (e.g., silica, mesoporous materials, zeolites), polymers etc. [31–37]. Apart from immobilized Rh-catalyst for the carbonylation of methanol to acetic acid, studies using other metals like Ni, Ir etc. are also reported [36–39,41]. Herein, we have reported the synthesis of two anchored Rh complexes (1a and 1b) prepared through complexation of [Rh(CO)2Cl]2 with two different quinoline carboxylic acids immobilized on APTMS functionalized activated montmorillonite clay (F-mont.). As a part of our continuing research activity [8,9,14,17,18,25–28,42], two N∼O donor ligand, quinoline-2-carboxylic acid (L1 ) and quinoline-8-carboxylic acid (L2 ) are taken for carrying out the carbonylation of methanol. L1 is immobilized on F-mont. resulting a and subsequent anchoring of [Rh(CO)2Cl]2 gives 1a. Similarly, immobilization of L2 on F-mont. results b and subsequent anchoring of [Rh(CO)2Cl]2 gives 1b. The anchored Rh complexes were evaluated as a catalyst precursor for the carbonylation of methanol to acetic acid with up to 99.9% conversion and only acetic acid was obtained as a single product without yielding methyl acetate as side product. Moreover, the catalyst precursors were very stable and can be easily separated from the reaction mixture by simple filtration. The catalysts were found very active for several runs without any significant loss of activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Bentonite (procured from Gujarat, India), containing quartz, iron oxide etc. as impurities, was purified by sedimentation technique to collect the montmorillonite clay (mont.) of <2μm fraction before use. PXRD analysis of the air dried purified fraction shows the basal spacing (d 001) to be about 12.5Å, which indicates that the purified fraction is mont. The surface area of the pure mont., determined by N2-sorption, was found about 101m2 g−1. The analytical oxide composition of the bentonite determined was SiO2: 49.42%; Al2O3: 20.02%; Fe2O3: 7.49%; MgO: 2.82%; CaO: 0.69%; loss on ignition (LOI): 17.51%; and others (Na2O, K2O and TiO2): 2.05%. All solvents were distilled under nitrogen environment prior to use. RhCl3·3H2O (Rh content 40%) was purchased from M/S Arrora Matthey Ltd., Kolkata, India. Quinoline-2-carboxylic acid and Quinoline-8-carboxylic acid ligands (98%) were purchased from M/S Aldrich, USA and used without further purification. Formic acid (98–99%), dichloromethane (99%), acetone (99%), toluene (99.5%), acetonitrile (99.5%), acetone and methanol (99.5%) were purchased from Sisco Research Laboratories Pvt., Ltd. (India) and used after distilled using standard techniques. Methyl iodide (99.5%), KBr (IR grade) and CHCl3 (IR grade) were purchased from M/S Merck, Germany and used without further purification. Carbon monoxide gas (99.9%) was purchased from Alchemie gases and chemicals Pvt., Ltd. (India). Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer. IR spectra (4000–400cm−1) were recorded in KBr discs and CHCl3 on a Shimadzu IR Affinity-1 spectrophotometer. The carbonylation reactions of methanol were carried out in a high pressure reactor (Parr-4592, USA) fitted with a pressure gauge and the reaction products were analyzed by GC (Chemito 8510, FID). Powder XRD spectra were recorded on a Rigaku, Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer for 2θ from 2° to 80° using Cu-Kα source (λ =1.54Å). Surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter were measured by N2 adsorption analysis using Autosorb-1 surface area analyser (Quantachrome USA). Surface areas of the samples were calculated applying the Branauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model. Prior to adsorption, the samples were degassed at 250°C for 3h. Pore size distributions were derived from desorption isotherms using Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were obtained with Leo 1430 vp operated at 3 and 10kV. Prior to examination, the samples were coated with gold. 2.2 Support preparation 10g of powdered mont. was dispersed in 500mL of 10M formic acid solution and refluxed for 16h. The whole mass was transferred to a beaker and the solvent was decanted off. The remaining mass was mixed with distilled water and centrifuged. Finally, the centrifuged mass was dialysed with distilled water till the conductance of the dialysed water becomes equal to that of pure distilled water. The whole mass was recovered and dried at 65°C. The sample thus prepared was designated as AT-mont. Analytical data for the prepared support are as follows: Yield: 9.945g, BET surface area: 257m2 g−1, average pore diameter: 47Å, pore volume: 0.30cm3 g−1, XRD data: 2θ =7.06°, 26°. 2.3 Preparation of Rhodium dimer [Rh(CO)2Cl]2 [Rh(CO)2Cl]2 was prepared by passing CO gas over RhCl3·3H2O at 100–110°C in the presence of moisture [29]. The red crystals were collected in a sample tube and kept in desiccators under vacuum. 2.4 Synthesis of APTMS functionalized AT-mont. 500mg of AT-mont.was added to 100mL of dry toluene. To this mixture 0.5mmol of APTMS was added and the resultant mixture was refluxed for 6h. After cooling, the solid was separated by filtration and washed repeatedly using soxhlet extraction with dry toluene as a solvent. The resultant material was dried and designated as F-mont. Analytical data for F-mont.: Yield: 490mg, FT-IR data (KBr) (cm−1): 1638, 2931, 3299, 29Si NMR (79.5MHz) δ(ppm): −93 and −110, CHN analysis data: C (10.86%), H (2.49%) and N (2.89%). 2.5 Synthesis of L1 and L2 immobilized F-mont In a suspension of 400mg F-mont.in 60mL acetone, 0.17mmol of L1 was added. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 4h. The solids were separated from the solvent by filtration and washed repeatedly using soxhlet extraction with DCM. The solid mass was air dried and kept in desiccators. The material was designated as a. The same process was repeated with ligand L2 and the material thus prepared was designated as b. Analytical data for a: Yield: 387mg, FT-IR data (KBr) (cm−1): 3444, 3419, 3367, 2940, 1707, 1635, 1465, 1381, CHN analysis data: C (12.56%), H (2.66%) and N (3.09%). Analytical data for b: Yield: 388mg, FT-IR data (KBr) (cm−1): 3443, 3430, 3311, 2939, 1708, 1634, 1471, 1384, CHN analysis data: C (12.69%), H (2.71%) and N (3.07%). 2.6 Immobilization of Rh complexes on a and b Anchoring of Rh complexes on a and b was done through complexation of [Rh(CO)2Cl]2 with the anchored ligand L1 and L2 on F-mont. 96.5mg of the dimer was added to a suspension of a (400mg) in acetonitrile and stirred for 30min under CO environment. The solid was then filtered and washed on the filter paper with acetonitrile to remove any un-anchored rhodium dimer. The mass was air dried, kept in desiccator and designated as 1a.The same procedure was followed using the material b and the material was designated as 1b. Analytical data for 1a:Yield: 390mg, FT-IR data (KBr) (cm−1): 3444, 3419, 3367, 2940, 2087, 2011, 1635, 1377, BET surface area: 87m2 g−1, pore diameter: 31Å, Pore volume: 0.24cm3 g−1, XRD data: 2θ =7.06°, 27°, 29Si NMR (79.5MHz) δ(ppm): −55, −65, −92, −107, 13C NMR (100.6MHz) δ(ppm): 21, 71, 124, CHN analysis data: C (12.93%), H (2.61%) and N (3.02%). Analytical data for 1b: Yield: 390mg, FT-IR data (KBr) (cm−1): 3443, 3430, 3311, 2939, 2082, 2010, 1634, 1471, 1370, BET surface area: 75m2 g−1, pore diameter: 55Å, Pore volume: 0.13cm3 g−1, XRD data: 2θ =7.06°, 27°, 29Si NMR (79.5MHz) δ(ppm): −47, −55, −65, −92, −107, 13C NMR (100.6MHz) δ(ppm): 25, CHN analysis data: C (12.98%), H (2.69%) and N (3.11%). 2.7 Catalytic carbonylation reaction 40mg of the catalyst (1a or 1b) with 1mL of CH3I was taken in the reaction vessel and kept for 1min. To it 4mL of CH3OH and 1mL of distilled water was added. Then the reactor was pressurized with CO gas to 10, 15 or 20bar at room temperature (r.t.). The reaction was carried out for 1h and 3h at 130±2°C with corresponding CO pressure 22±2, 27±2 or 33±2bar respectively. After the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by simple filtration and the products were analyzed by GC. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the support The PXRD pattern of the purified montmorillonite exhibited a basal reflection at 2θ value of 7.06° corresponding to a basal spacing of 12.5Å (Fig. 1 [A]). The intensity reflection 2θ equal to 7.06° for basal spacing and 28° for amorphous silica of the clay remained almost same after the acid activation, which indicates no disruption of layered structure of the clay took place. The N2-sorption isotherm of the AT-mont. shows a type-IV isotherm with H2 hysteresis loop at relative pressure range, P/P 00.4–0.9, which indicates a mesoporous nature of the support (Fig. 1[B]). A sharp fall of the desorption branches for both parent mont. and AT-mont. at P/P 0 0.4–0.5 were observed which are due to the sudden emptying of filled gas from the internal layers of clay structure (for parent mont.) and disordered pores (for AT-mont.). The BET surface area of AT-mont. calculated from the isotherm was found to be 257m2 g−1 with a pore volume of 0.30cm3 g−1 and a pore diameter ranging from15 to 200Å with an average pore diameter of 47Å, whereas the parent mont. (Fig. 1[B]) exihibits a surface area of 101m2 g−1 with pore volume and pore diameter 0.22cm3 g−1 and 33Å respectively. The increase of the surface area is due to the controlled leaching of Al3+ ion from montmorillonite clay without destroying layer structure. The 29Si NMR showed two peaks at −93 and −109ppm due to presence of (OH)2Si(OSi)2 and HOSi(OSi)3 silicon species [43–45] in the AT-mont. with two and three SiOSi linkages respectively. No peak in 13C NMR was observed in the AT-mont. confirming the absence of any organic moiety. 3.2 Characterization of F-mont The FT-IR spectra of the F-mont. exhibits a peak at 3299cm−1, due to the NH stretching, which indicates the immobilization of APTMS onto AT-mont. (Fig. 2 ). Elemental analysis of this material shows the presence of C, H and N in the material which thereby confirms the functionalization of APTMS. 3.3 Ligand immobilization and in-situ Rh complexation of F-mont The FT-IR analyses showed a new peak at 1707cm−1 for the CO group of the ligand L1 , thereby confirming the immobilization of L1 on F-mont. (ESI: Fig. 1). A band of low intensity at 1381cm−1was also observed due to CN stretching. Same trend was also observed for b, which indicates the immobilization of L2 on F-mont. (ESI: Fig. 1). The FT-IR spectra after anchoring of Rh complex to a and b show two peaks in the range 2081–2005cm−1 due to the two carbonyl CO attached in cis position to the Rh metal center. It was also observed that, there were no changes in the NH stretching frequency (ESI: Fig. 1) of the immobilized ligands on F-mont., which suggest that coordination of the Rh metal to the ligand is taking place through the N-atom of the quinoline ring (Scheme 1 ). The presence of Rh in 1a and 1b was confirmed by SEM-EDX analysis (Fig. 3 ) which thereby indicates the anchoring of the Rh-complex on F-mont. N2-sorption analysis (Fig. 4 ) shows a decrease in the BET surface area of 1a and 1b to 87 and 75m2 g−1from 257m2 g−1 (for AT-mont.) respectively. This indicates the immobilizations are taking place in the surface of the pore resulting decrease of BET surface area. The 29Si NMR of 1a (Fig. 5 ) showed two new peaks at −55 and −66ppm due to the presence of RSi(OH)(OSi)2 and RSi(OSi)3 silicon species [43–46], which illustrate that the amine groups were grafted onto the montmorillonite by covalent bonds. Moreover, the resonance of the peaks at −93 and −109ppm in AT-mont. to −92 and 107ppm were observed. The high intensity of the −66ppm peak clearly indicates that majority of the APTMS bind to the support through all the three O atom of the methoxy groups. In the 29Si NMR of 1b (Fig. 5) an additional low intense peak was observed at −47ppm due to RSi(OH)2(OSi). This indicates the presence of APTMS species in 1b with two free methoxy groups in a minor amount. 3.4 Catalytic carbonylation reaction The catalytic activity of 1a and 1b were evaluated in carbonylation of methanol (Scheme 2 ) for reaction time of 1 and 3h (Table 1 ). 1a and 1b showed a maximum total conversion up to 56.3 and 58.8% respectively at 20bar initial pressure in 1h reaction time with corresponding TOF 1122 and 1172h−1, with methyl acetate as the major product, which is marginally higher than the commercial Monsanto’s species (TOF=1000) [40]. It has been observed that, increase in the initial CO pressure from 10bar to 20bar enhance the TOF by 115 and 128h−1 for 1a and 1b respectively. This indicates that the catalyst is also active at low CO pressure. On increasing the reaction time to 3h, both 1a and 1b showed near 100% conversion with acetic acid as single product compared to 1h reaction time. The methyl acetate formed during initial reaction may get hydrolysed to acetic acid in the 3h reaction time by the support AT-mont., which also acts as solid acid catalyst. To check the heterogeneity of the catalyst 1a and 1b, hot filtration test was performed in order to check the leaching of the catalyst at 20bar pressure. During the test, catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration after 1h of reaction and the products were analysed using GC. The filtrate was further allowed for 1h reaction time under the same reaction condition, but no increase in the reaction products was observed. This clearly indicates that there was no leaching of the Rh complex from the support. The reusability of 1a and 1b were also evaluated by recycling up to third run for 3h reaction time. The catalysts were recovered from the reaction mixture by simple filtration, washed with acetone and dried in vacuum desiccator for next run. The subsequent runs were carried out by maintaining the same stoichiometric ratio of catalyst and substrate. The catalyst remains active in the subsequent runs without significant loss of efficiency and can be reused for several runs. The FT-IR spectra of the catalyst 1a after third run shows the presence of a terminal CO peak at 2063cm−1, the CN stretching at 1465cm−1and a CN stretching at 1381cm−1 (ESI: Fig. 2) of the qiunoline group which remained unchanged from that of the freshly prepared catalyst and thereby confirms the presence of NRh bond. The CO peak at 2063cm−1 indicates the presence of Rh in +3 oxidation state. The methyl iodide regenerated after completion of the reaction always reacts with the regenerated Rh(I) species through oxidative addition to form Rh(III) species. The integrity of the catalysts 1a and 1b after each cycle was confirmed from the similar type of N2-sorption isotherm and PXRD pattern (ESI: Fig. 3). The catalysts 1a and 1b also exhibited a better catalytic activity in comparison to other already reported heterogeneous catalysts [12,39,46]. Moreover, 1a and 1b give only acetic acid as single product in 3h reaction time. The methyl acetate formed during reaction in other process as a by-product will need an additional hydrolysis process to convert it to acetic acid. A comparative study of 1a and 1b with different heterogeneous catalyst for methanol carbonylation is shown in Table 2 . The catalysts in the present work are more advantageous in comparison to the other reported heterogeneous carbonylation catalyst in terms of stability, reusability without any loss of catalytic efficiency and easy separation. 4 Conclusion Formic acid activated montmorillonite clay was functionalized using APTMS and the ligand L1 and L2 were immobilized on the surface resulting a and b respectively. Two new Rh complexes anchored catalytic precursors 1a and 1b were synthesized by using a and b respectively. 1a and 1b were characterized using various spectroscopic and analytical techniques. The catalysts 1a and 1b showed efficient carbonylation of methanol to produce only acetic acid after 3h of reaction time. The catalysts were recovered by simple filtration and reused upto third run and found active without any significant loss of efficiency. Acknowledgments The authors are grateful to Dr. D. coredata.dc:description: The catalyst precursors, [Rh(CO)2Cl-ligand(L)-APTMS-montmorillonite] (1a and 1b, where, a and b correspond to ligand (L)-APTMS-montmorillonite for ligands L=Quinoline-2-carboxylic acid (L1) and Quinoline-8-carboxylic acid (L2) respectively; APTMS=(3-aminopropyl)-trimethoxysilane), have been synthesised. The montmorillonite was activated by treating with formic acid under controlled condition to increase the surface area and pore volume prior to functionalization by APTMS and subsequent anchoring with the ligands. 1a and 1b were characterized by CHN, FT-IR, powder XRD, N2-sorption and SEM-EDX analysis. The efficacy of the catalysts was evaluated in carbonylation of methanol to acetic acid and found to exhibit catalytic conversion up to 99.9%. The catalysts were recovered and reused for several runs without any significant loss of catalytic efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: Functionalized montmorillonite supported rhodium complexes: Efficient catalysts for carbonylation of methanol
